text:
The property covers portions of the western and southeastern flanks of the Widgiemooltha Dome 
 where  a  northnorthwesterly  trending  tightly  folded  and  faulted  layered  Archaean  greenstone 
 succession  has  been  intruded  by  a  large  monzogranite  complex.    A  similar  granitoid  complex 
 known as the Pioneer Dome disrupts the greenstone succession in southeastern parts. 
 Nickel sulphide mineralisation in the district is associated with magnesium rich komatiitic lava 
 flows and is particularly significant at the base of channel flow facies deposits.  These contact 
 style deposits may occur at different stratigraphic horizons but are often linked to the lowermost 
 channel flow volcanic event.  Nickel sulphide mineralisation of this style often comprises a lower 
 massive sulphide zone overlain by a matrix sulphide zone and a halo of disseminated sulphides. 
 Typically, these deposits are tabular or ribbon-like or are made up of a series of pod-like bodies 
 In general terms, gold mineralisation in the district is associated with a wide range of Archaean 
 rock types and associations including with quartz-pyrite veins along contact zones between felsic 
 and mafic-ultramafic rock types, in quartz veins associated with felsic rocks, in quartz veins and 
 disseminated  sulphide  alteration  zones  in  mafic  rocks  and  vein  quartz  associated  with 
 metasedimentary rock

and structure of the bedrock geology relies on the interpretation of remote sensing surveys and 
 the direct evidence from drilling.

12.text: greenstone  sequence  comprising  intercalated  mafic  and  ultramafic  units  including  komatiite

13.text: overlain by felsic volcaniclastic sediments.  Archaean granitoids intrude the greenstone sequence

15.text: greenstone succession.  The most prominent example of the dykes is the gabbroic Binneringie

19.text: Archaean  terrain  underlain  by  granitoids  and  limited  portions  of  the  western  flank  of  the

20.text: Widgiemooltha  Dome  where  faulted  parts  of  the  Archaean  greenstone  sequence  may  occur

21.text: masked  by  superficial  cover.    Regional  magnetic  data  indicate  northnorthwesterly  trending

22.text: linears  through  central  portions  of  the  tenement  which  may  represent  concealed  narrow

23.text: greenstone belts between intrusive granitoids or major fault zones.  In the south of the tenement,

24.text: eastnortheasterly  trending  magnetic  zones  are  probably  linked  to  Proterozoic  mafic  dyke

text:
Current  interpretation  of  the  bedrock  geology  suggests  a  highly  folded  layered  Archaean 
 greenstone  sequence  comprising  intercalated  mafic  and  ultramafic  units  including  komatiite 
 overlain by felsic volcaniclastic sediments.  Archaean granitoids intrude the greenstone sequence 
 and  undeformed  eastnortheasterly  trending  mafic  dykes  of  Proterozoic  age  crosscut  the 
 greenstone succession.  The most prominent example of the dykes is the gabbroic Binneringie 
 The  western  tenement  area,  Exploration  Licence  Application  15/837,  covers  poorly  exposed 
 Archaean  terrain  underlain  by  granitoids  and  limited  portions  of  the  western  flank  of  the 
 Widgiemooltha  Dome  where  faulted  parts  of  the  Archaean  greenstone  sequence  may  occur 
 masked  by  superficial  cover.    Regional  magnetic  data  indicate  northnorthwesterly  trending 
 linears  through  central  portions  of  the  tenement  which  may  represent  concealed  narrow 
 greenstone belts between intrusive granitoids or major fault zones.  In the south of the tenement, 
 eastnortheasterly  trending  magnetic  zones  are  probably  linked  to  Proterozoic  mafic  dyke 
 The Archaean greenstone sequence has been affected by four deformation events to produce an 
 isoclinally  folded  succession  trending  northnorthwest.    This  regional  trend  is  affected  by  the 
 monzogranite complex forming the Widgiemooltha Dome which lies off property in the northern 
 sector  and  to  a  lesser  degree  by  the  monzogranite  complex  forming  the  Pioneer  Dome  in  the

10.text: eastnortheasterly  trend  accommodates  the  major  Proterozoic  Binneringie  Dyke  which  passes

11.text: through Exploration Licence 15/625.  This extensional faulting phase is reflected in a number of

12.text: additional faults with a similar trend.

15.text: Nickel sulphide mineralisation on the property has been intersected by drilling with values up to

16.text: 1.07 % nickel over 12 metres from 60 metres in aircore hole WMAC126.  Cuttings from this hole

17.text: have been studied petrographically and the sulphides present include pentlandite partly replaced

18.text: by bravoite, chalcopyrite, pyrite and trace marcasite and sphalerite.

21.text: Exploration in the modern era began in the late 1960s and covered minor portions of the southern

22.text: margin of Exploration Licence 15/625 and extensive areas off property to the south where the

23.text: focus was nickel sulphide exploration related to ultramafic sequences on the western and eastern

24.text: flanks of the Pioneer Dome.  For the eastern tenement group this work confirmed that a mafic

25.text: and  ultramafic  sequence  extended  northward  into  Exploration  Licence  15/625  north  and

26.text: northeast of the northern boundary of the Pioneer Dome.

28.text: In separate programmes, exploration for nickel was carried out intermittently between 1969 and

29.text: 1974 over areas which covered parts of the northern sector of Exploration Licence 15/625.  This

30.text: work  was  designed  to  test  for  basal  portions  of  magnetically  inferred  ultramafic  units.    A

31.text: prospective area for nickel exploration was identified.

text:
eastnortheasterly  trend  accommodates  the  major  Proterozoic  Binneringie  Dyke  which  passes 
 through Exploration Licence 15/625.  This extensional faulting phase is reflected in a number of 
 additional faults with a similar trend. 
 Nickel sulphide mineralisation on the property has been intersected by drilling with values up to 
 1.07 % nickel over 12 metres from 60 metres in aircore hole WMAC126.  Cuttings from this hole 
 have been studied petrographically and the sulphides present include pentlandite partly replaced 
 by bravoite, chalcopyrite, pyrite and trace marcasite and sphalerite. 
 4.1 Early Nickel Exploration 1968 to 1974 
 Exploration in the modern era began in the late 1960s and covered minor portions of the southern 
 margin of Exploration Licence 15/625 and extensive areas off property to the south where the 
 focus was nickel sulphide exploration related to ultramafic sequences on the western and eastern 
 flanks of the Pioneer Dome.  For the eastern tenement group this work confirmed that a mafic 
 and  ultramafic  sequence  extended  northward  into  Exploration  Licence  15/625  north  and 
 northeast of the northern boundary of the Pioneer Dome. 
 In separate programmes, exploration for nickel was carried out intermittently between 1969 and 
 1974 over areas which covered parts of the northern sector of Exploration Licence 15/625.  This 
 work  was  designed  to  test  for  basal  portions  of  magnetically  inferred  ultramafic  units.    A 
 prospective area for nickel exploration was identified.

17.text: The  drilling  programmes  proved  an  ultramafic  and  mafic  sequence  beneath  cover  over  the

18.text: northern  sector  of  Exploration  Licence  15/625  and  led  to  the  discovery  of  several  significant

19.text: intersections  associated  in  serpentinised  ultramafics  with  a  peak  value  of  1.12%  nickel  and

20.text: 0.31%  chromium  over  2  metres  from  144  metres  in  hole  RCRED  490.   Some  elevated  nickel

21.text: values  were  associated  with  porphyry  intrusions  in  ultramafics.    Further  details  are  shown  on

22.text: Table 7.  The two drill traverses used to investigate magnetic anomalies over a constrained area

23.text: in the south failed to intersect significant nickel values.

25.text: In  addition  to  the  above  activities,  geochemical  soil  sampling  was  carried  out  over  southern

26.text: sections of Exploration Licence 15/625 along with some reconnaissance drilling along the eastern

27.text: parts of the property but these data are sparsely documented.

text:
hole geophysical surveying was possible. 
 Drill samples were selectively analysed for nickel, chromium, cobalt, zinc and gold at variable 
 drill sample intervals based on geology.  However, most mafic and ultramafic sequences were 
 sampled over 2 or 1 metre intervals. 
 The  drilling  programmes  proved  an  ultramafic  and  mafic  sequence  beneath  cover  over  the 
 northern  sector  of  Exploration  Licence  15/625  and  led  to  the  discovery  of  several  significant 
 intersections  associated  in  serpentinised  ultramafics  with  a  peak  value  of  1.12%  nickel  and 
 0.31%  chromium  over  2  metres  from  144  metres  in  hole  RCRED  490.   Some  elevated  nickel 
 values  were  associated  with  porphyry  intrusions  in  ultramafics.    Further  details  are  shown  on 
 Table 7.  The two drill traverses used to investigate magnetic anomalies over a constrained area 
 in the south failed to intersect significant nickel values. 
 In  addition  to  the  above  activities,  geochemical  soil  sampling  was  carried  out  over  southern 
 sections of Exploration Licence 15/625 along with some reconnaissance drilling along the eastern 
 parts of the property but these data are sparsely documented.

The company reviewed all previous exploration with specific emphasis on the potential for nickel 
 and  gold  mineralisation.  Rock  chips  from  mineralised  section  of  WRAC  126  were  sent  for 
 petrographic  study  and  the  presence  of  pentlandite,  bravoite,  chalcopyrite  and  pyrite  was 
 Jupiter  also  commissioned  an  interpretation  of  imagery  developed  from  aeromagnetic  data 
 available over the licence area.  In all 16 targets based on the magnetic images were identified.   
 Six of the targets were considered nickel targets, two gold and nickel targets and the remainder

text:
5. Exploration  2006 to 2007 
 P15/4639 was accessed for potential nickel targets that would be enhanced by being included in a 
 large scale Moving Loop TEM Survey conducted by Outerrim. The tenement is dominated by 
 interpreted non magnetic Archaean sediments. The sediments are not associated with ultramafic 
 Aerial photos of P15/4639 were assessed and due the depth cover over the area failed to delineate 
 any new features or aid in further exploration targets. At this stage the magnetic are by far the 
 best interpretive data over the tenement.  
 No nickel mineralisation targets of note were delineated during this program. The Moving Loop 
 TEM Survey over the project area this year could not included P15/4639. E15/625 and P15/4639 
 in exploration terms have been treated as one tenement as P15/4639 is very small and forms one 
 small portion of a continuous lease.
